titleInfo.title: When It's Time to Take Your Eye off the Ball
titleInfo.subTitle: Preparation for Life after Collegiate Sport

name.namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems

mods:mods.abstract: Collegiate athletes are at risk of exposure to crises-like outcomes when transitioning out of their sport. These outcomes include anxiety (Alfermann, 2000), depression (Brewer et al., 1993), reduced self-worth, identity confusion (Park et al., 2013), and social dysfunction (Blakelock et al., 2016; Brown & Potrac, 2009; Gouttebarge et al., 2016). This study involved the development and testing of an intervention aimed at reducing these outcomes. Specifically, the intervention was developed to educate collegiate student-athletes about the potential challenges and psychological changes they could expect to experience when retiring from their sport, and to offer strategies that the student-athletes can employ when navigating these retirement difficulties. Participants recruited for the study were current NCAA collegiate student-athletes in the United States. Measures included participants' knowledge of the retirement process, their behaviors in preparation for the retirement process, their perceptions of social support, and athletic identity. Participants completed a pre-test comprising these measures. Participants were then randomly assigned to a control or treatment group. Participants in the control group viewed a 14-minute sport retirement video presentation about facts about NCAA retirement (e.g., advanced education attainment among NCAA student-athletes) that were not theorized to be related to the key challenges of retirement or relevant coping strategies. The treatment group viewed a 14-minute sport retirement education video presentation that concerned concepts theorized to be related to the key challenges of retirement and relevant coping strategies. Participants then completed a post-test and a four-week follow-up test comprising the study measures. Findings revealed that, in relation to the control condition, the intervention significantly increased participants' perceived knowledge about sport retirement challenges, but had no significant effect on the remaining variables. In conclusion, this study has provided some evidence that the intervention developed for this study might be useful in raising awareness in student-athletes of the retirement process. Applied implications of this research study are considered for student-athletes, coaches, parents, and sport organizations including the NCAA. Recommended avenues of future research are also outlined.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Athletic Retirement, Collegiate Sport, Sport Retirement, Sport Termination
David W. Eccles, Professor Directing Dissertation; Jesse R. Cougle, University Representative; Robert C. Eklund, Committee Member; Martin A. Swanbrow Becker, Committee Member.
